column1: omment_message
'Listening to Boris sounded like he was reading from a script issued to him by the US. At least he managed not to insult anyone though.'
'Well said, Clare Bishop.'
'https://www.facebook.com/worldeconomicforum/videos/10154276980221479/'
'Great article...the best reasons for voting for our great party.'
'Hear hear, keep the good work up x'
'Well said Clare.'
"Clare. Don't use the word fascism again until you have some idea of what it means."
'Did like the two apostrophes on children though. Typical Lib Dem. Cant make your mind up '
' you criticize her use of apostrophe and then say "cant". '
'Oh look. A Kipperite.'
'And the surge towards facism is happening all around the world. Just open your eyes!'
'Brexit was a democratic vote. Tell we where the fascism is for the snowflakes?'
'Conservative. Realist. Brexiter. And you James?'

"Fascism to me means imposing your one way and one view of life on everyone, rather than celebrating diversity and welcoming multiculturalism. That's why I believe Kippers are at least verging on fascism."
'And you are one Dominic.'
'Fifty years ago, Conservatives were one nation people who supported civic society and Britain playing its part in the world. Now the Conservatives are no longer such a party. UKIP in all but name.'

"Well Claire I sort of agree, since fascism is the belief that only an elite can properly govern , it's there in the theocratic fascism of Islam . I've also seen it in the attempts to undermine the result of the democratic referendum"

"My parents were active Conservatives in the 1960s. My Mum is sadly no longer with us, but I know they were both heartily sickened by Thatcher's view of Europe and her uncaring attitude towards those less fortunate than her, and I'm very proud they found a new political home in my party."

'No one is undermining a vote. The only party so far trying to undermine anything is the conservatives. They are the party trying to force things through without scrutiny and having to be pulled into line by the courts. Lindems want you to have more say not less.'
'Alan - I would expect nothing more from a Kipper. I should I say less ?'

'Comparing brexit with fascism. Fascism killed million, fascism involved genocide and misery. Yet you compare that to brexit! Without realising you just laid down the epitome of middle class first world problems." It may be a bit more difficult for me to go on European holidays or send my kids on a gap it yah, now i know how victims of fascism felt when they lost their homes, family members and friends" ffs!'

'Dominic Barratt to deny a voice to huge swathes of our community in the referendum, tax paying citizens of the EU, and British citizens abroad for more than 10 years, is the very embodiment of fascism.'

"Chris Wright i lost the majority of my family to the last rise of fascism in Europe, I don't need your trite apologist nonsense of compare and contrast. A glaring and major part of Brexit is routed in nationalistic fascist ideology."
"Alan Skelhorn Please can you quote a single example of islam's theocratic fascism. Do you even know the difference forms of democracy and which we as a sovereign nation legally subscribe to?"
'How did you lose "the majority of your family to the last rise of fascism in Europe"?'
'Dominic Barratt, who are you to ask that question of Barnaby?! It is none of your business how he lost members of his family in that war.'
'Well said Barnaby Hulbert.'
"My father fought in WW2 at the age of 18 so that people had freedom including the freedom to ask questions. Don't try and close down free speech snowflake."

"Dominic Barratt no Brexit is not in itself fascist but the forces pushing it like Ukip do have fascist tendencies as do many of their supporters.Attempting to shut down debate, often through aggressive language such as 'snowflake ' 'libtard' and 'remoaners ' is also fascistic. I have been sent pictures of Hitler with messages glorifying the Holocaust when remainers realised I live in Poland. There is a general undercurrent of this that has to be challenged and your father would probably challenge it too.The freedom your father fought for is also the freedom to question the wisdom of Brexit and the way it's being (mis) handled"
"Dominic Barratt Nationalist based fascism, surely you can't be so opinionated and so ignorant at the same time, well perhaps you can if you believe it's possible to be a realist and a Brexiteer..."

'Dominic Barratt My father lied about his age and signed up at 16 to spend 3.5 years on axtuve service fighting the Nazis across Europe and got shot in the process. Most joined for glory and adventure and they all soon found out the horrific cost of such youthful folly, but they were young, whats your excuses? Brexit is not only steeped in a fascistic nationalism it is also based on a folly that can not deliver any benefit to most who back it.'
'So great that you are puttingtime and energy into a really good cause. Really well done!'
'Well said Clare I have recearly joined LIB Dems No other home for right thinking democrats'
"I hope it didn't cost you anything because then you really have been ripped off."
"It's a bargain A party without HATE Unlike Tories and UKIP"
'Was going well until Fascism, time to chill!'

"Would you say Trump is verging on fascist?! I would. Farage is the other side of the same coin. He drove the discourse on our leaving the EU. His friends in the Mail/Express etc pushed an unrelenting stream of divisive lies - often focussed squarely on outright lies regarding immigration. The Leave campaign also used the same kind of campaign approaches as the Nazi's. So to suggest there is no link to fascism is to completely ignore the evidence before you"
'Has anyone heard of "self-fulfilling prophecies "?'

'Clare, "I\'m a labourer from the North-East. I\'m sorry that my Fascistic leanings burst your little trans-continental bubble of smugness and self-interest. But, I\'m afraid I don\'t relate to your \'struggle\' and don\'t intend to, so long as I feel it comes at the expense of my interests; which it may come to shock you, are equally valid". Signed, Joe Everyman.'
'Lol how dare you Jonny, how very dare you! '

"Yeah, well known 'labourer from the North East ' Joe everyman,what a load of bull . Even if you were one what do you think anyone would care? Think this is a class struggle? It's a struggle between the educated and clueless, if you're for Brexit you are clueless simply. It's not ideology, it's reality which some refuse to face. When you are wrapped up in having 'won' it's easy to lose sight of the fact you are actually losing."
'Thanks for making a stronger argument in my favour than I ever could. Keep it up. '

"What argument would that be? That educated people are 'smug ' because they know things? You trying to promote the nobility of ignorance? Well good luck with that. And I take it your ' interests' as you put it basically revolve round paying more for stuff, losing working rights and a huge crash in the UK economy. Well don't expect us to respect your interests because they are in nobodies interest, including your own."

"I voted leave and I'm studying towards a degree. I know various other people in higher education or who work in trades and business, the military who voted leave too. I looked at reports from IEA and civitas. I read up on it. I voted out. I didn't vote the way you would have looked Stuart. I suppose you think we should have joined the Euro too? Your spitefulness and arrogance is unfortunately not uncommon for the remain camp. It does you know favours what so ever."
'Chris Wright What degree are you looking for? In Dead Empire Mythology? Of course you should join euro - you will be in the moment almost 20% richer with lower prices in your supermarkets. :P'

"Spiteful how? More than your witty opening gambit of a fake 'labourer 'comment.i really don't think you have a clue about the likely impact of Brexit. Getting your information from right -wing 'think tanks ' is nothing to be proud of. They are specifically designed to push the agenda for billionaires who are itching to turn the UK into a tax haven. Being in the military certainly doesn't qualitfy you for a noteworthy opinion either.unlike say being an economist of whom 90% believe it will be 'devastating ' to the UK economy. Thinking yourself clever than those people is the true barometer of arrogance. And you need to check your spelling and grammar in your comments before taking a high and mighty tone with others, it does your argument 'know' favours whatsoever"

"Exactly my point. Enact a democratic decision, receive sniping condescending remarks from the people we are in the union with. Classic. This is my very point, you ask about the degree that i am studying, and its relevance to such a vote. Usually the smug remain camp,( I'm not going to tar all remain voters as this) holding a degree is the gold standard when it comes to this vote, even if its in something like English lit, or gender studies etc. I had an interest in politics. I read up on the subjects. I didn't like the EU and the way its going. I exercised my democratic vote, i voted out. Deal with it."

'My grammar and spelling might be bad as I\'m writing on my mobile phone so apologies. That is another hallmark argument "you\'re writing is bad so nerrrr " Most universities are left wing institutions, large swathes of academia are anti business, Pro large government, central planning etc. Are we going to go with the sixth form right wing=bad, left wing=good argument then Stuart? Also that wasn\'t my witty opening liner. I did however find it vaguely amusing. Still i suppose things like the please my simple working class brain right?'

"Chris Wright seems.i confused you with the first commenter but the rest of what I said stands. It really doesn't impress me that you are studying for a degree,I already have one in Economics as it happens. Remainers aren't arrogant or 'moaning ' .They can see a catastrophe in the making and are scared.if you lot weren't so blinded by dogma you would be too.soon even you'll notice"

"Well said Clare and all so true. The so called referendum was a total farce. The result was practically 50/50 and even on the day of it Nigel Farage was refusing to accept the result of a close outcome until he found out it had gone his way! There is an old saying that 'You can fool some of the people some of the time, but you can't fool all of the people all of the time'. Those 'Leaver Deceivers' are being found out day by day, hence their desperation to not let the public have a final say. No matter, they have to try and hang on to their result for ever and some of them may well see it overturned. It's a long road without a bend and lots can happen, sooner or later it will bend our way. The true will of the British people will triumph in the end. Even if we do leave, we'll rejoin again at some point and many of us will never stop campaigning until that happens. Let's face it, a monkey randomly throwing bananas at two empty tea chests would probably get about 50/50 in each. We deserve a much more informed and reasoned outcome than that!"

"It's a long time since I was in sixth form Chris Wright.Maybe fresher in your mind Perhaps if you could attempt to point out a single tangible economic benefit from Brexit, rather than simply complaining about the 'arrogance ' of people for opposing it.As I said,if you strip away the ideology, there is no sound economic basis for Brexit. If you can come up with one it'll be a first."
"Chris Wright I await anxiously the fruits of your vigorous research which proves we won't be considerably worse off outside the single market."

"This is what i read initially. You'll have to forgive me. Its 2 am in the morning. I am up at 6. I read this report as well as also watching seminars by capital economics. I actually study the social sciences so i don't have time to trawl through and trawl through. I dedicate most of my time to my studies. http://www.civitas.org.uk/press/trade-advantages-of-the-eu-are-imaginary/"

"What are you thoughts on European federalisation? I'll be honest. If there was reform and the EU scaled back to just the initial trading agreement which Britain had with what was the common market, i wouldn't mind so much."

"Chris Wright I have lots of friends who voted leave, in various professional fields. I have friends who voted leave who are in minimum wage jobs, no academic education. I have friends who voted remain in both circumstances as above. Some voted with information they read from various sources, some did so for a very strong emotional feeling. The fact remains that it does not matter why you voted the way you did. It does not matter one bit. You could argue inadequacy and lack of knowledge on both sides. You could argue that whichever side is against you is wrong. Again, it does not matter. What matters here is where we are heading. I am sick to my teeth of hearing this government stirring emotions on poor people, those who are very vulnerable of being manipulated. I am sick of how they still are peddling untruths like the one referenced in the first comment on this thread: The EU is to blame for everything that has gone wrong in your life! Labourers are not poorer because we are in the EU, they are poorer because in an economic model based on financial services and driven by consumerism you need to keep all investment and subsidies in the enterprise that is making you money. Have you ever wondered why is cheaper to bring apples from Africa than it is to grow them here? I believe you immediately are going to blame some obscure idea that has come from the EU, however many other countries IN the EU manage just great to grow their own produce. We don't. The government has taken every subsidy and investment and infrastructure project and has placed it on the service industry, basically the financial services to keep them competitive, and everyone can buy our main exporting 'product'. They've not done so with other industries and no one in this country has said anything at all for many years, as we all have enjoyed the benefits of this booming economic success! We have always had sovereignty, we've always have had border control, even more so than any other EU member states, but the government is quite happy not only to allow people to believe, but to fuel this belief that the EU is responsible for all your woes and worries. The problem I see is not leaving the EU, but leaving the single market and the ECC, both of which are crucial to sustain the industry that has supported the economic model of the UK. Have you recently read on how we 'may have to' accept migration isn't going to go down for a long while? And that we 'may have to accept' that we will have to pay a lot of money to keep the parts we want? None of the issues that fueled many people to vote leave are going to be resolved, but the government has seen a great opportunity to 'white-wash' all their wrongs to strengthen their political position. That's what I find such an evil control move."

"Chris Wright the think tank report seems at first impressive until you consider two things. The think tank itself is a fairly shady one with opaque sources of funding. In most cases these things aren't academic institutions but set up to push an agenda,in this case a radical 'free market ' one.secondly, the report has no facts only assertions. It fails to mention loss of 'passporting rights ' for our finance and services sector which make up 80% of our GDP. Nor does it recognise the fact that we host many multi national companies who are based here due to our access to EU markets.The fact that our agriculture sector would be devastated by trade restrictions and loss of seasonal labour. There are many other issues which you'll start noticing being mentioned on the news soon. The reason you give for leaving is 'sovereignty '.This is bases on the lie that the EU has any sovereign powers.Mostly it regulates product and services,employment protections and environmental issues. These we will most likely stick to anyway if we wish to trade with the EU. We gain nothing effectively whilst losing a lot exotically. You also lose right to live and work on the EU and all the benefits that brings. It's basically a huge expense and risk to get back something we never lost"
"Leave out 'the Brexit slogans - deal with it' etc in that phrase I feel your fury. Get over yourself - sound familiar."
'Wot a silly bunt you are....narrow minded ,short term thinking (or more precisely lack of thinking) leads to fascist war pigs running riot in Europe. Read books, research...then comment.'
'Stuart Adamson, I am a Remainer through and through, but I have to say that in your responses to Chris Wright you sound patronising and arrogant. His responses are a good deal more measured.'

"John Duncan how is it arrogant to explain something? There is only one truth here,either Brexit is a good thing economically or it isn't . according to most polls the vast majority of leavers believe they can do it without economic costs. Pointing it out is no more arrogant than a doctor telling you that smoking is harmful. There's a lot of vague assertions that Brexit will be positive based on nothing versus a massive weight of evidence to the contrary. I have also argued with climate change deniers who also cited 'evidence ' from think tanks and called me arrogant.the truth will eventually dawn on leavers but the sooner the better.so call me arrogant for pointing out home truths if you like but that's the nature of free debate."
'Well said Clare.'
"Barnaby Hulbert You weren't denied a voice. We voted. You lost. You whined. Life went on. No denial of anything."
"*We all lost. You just haven't woken up to that reality yet."
'Actually, we all won.'
"I was denied a voice Dominic Barratt, as we're many British ex pats.Is that democracy for you?"

'Every single comment by the leavers in this thread shows how important people like Clare are to democracy and freedom. Those who disagree with her verbally abuse her and want her to go quietly in to the night. We will not. Our views are as valid as the Leavers who wish us not to have any. Leavers fought for 41 years to overturn the 1975 referendum result. Remainers have a greater right to do the same due to how close the 2016 result was. We will not just shut up because Leavers tell us to.'
"Telling Remainers to stop campaigning to remain is a form of fascism. Democracy didn't end on 23 June 16."
'Just read what the quitlings write their is a policy of divide and conquer.'
'Sounds good. I see the Lib Dems as close to the Ciudadanos from Spain in many respects.'
'What I like about these stories is that most seem to go from joining to some sort of responsibility very quickly - underlining that you are still a small organisation.'
'Well said '
'Captured my feelings.. Well said'
"My neck of the woods (I'm from Buntingford). It's important for us to make our voices heard!"
'Well said.'
' [[STICKER]]'
'So right, Carol Stanier.'
'Feeling very positive that we are in the recovery position at last. Keep it up with such positive messages. X'
"Debra Manning She's from our parts :D"
'Go Carol! A real pleasure to get to know you. Sorry I cant help out this time, but look forward to working with you in the future xx'

"I agree with all you have said here and I would have loved to be able to turn to the Liberal Democrats and feel that they have a strong and credible position to challenge Brexit. However out of all of the political parties, LibDems have shown to me, at least, the weakest challenges for a number of years and today they seem to have a commentary rather than authoritative voice. It's a crying shame that the middle-left no longer has a voice. Very sad."
'What patronising rubbish.'
'Mr Hill and mr Chester. Why do you feel so insecure that you have to troll?'
"Hi there! Are you still after these contributions, as I'd be happy to send in mine. Thanks."
'Sensitive to refugees!sorry jiladist s ! Allowing them to sexually assault !rape kill at will and claim their innocent and escaping war.'

"I completely agree Carol about equal immigration rights for everyone. Currently we have a system where 27 white European countries get unlimited access, while harsher limits are imposed on the rest of the world. Fortunately we're leaving the EU, so we can design a fair immigration system that welcomes everyone. Now...where do I sign please?"

"CAROL YOU SAID YOU THINK FOR YOURSELF BUT YOU DON'T. All the same old soft soap. We are not a big enough country to take everyone who wants to come here. WHY NOT HELP REFUGEES TAKE SOME RESPONSIBILITY FOR THEMSELVES AND DO SOMETHING TO REFORM THERE OWN COUNTRIES."

'Liberal Democrats arent playing party politics. Instead, they are a movement, a movement for Freedom, Openness, Unity and Prosperity. This can be seen from the recent Membership hike. Unlike the fake inflated Membership in UK Labour Party.'

"They are the party that betrayed their voters and PUT the Tories in power. They did for their own greed. And they aren't the ones suffering for that act they committed. An action they feel no guilt for."
"I'm pretty sure the voters put the Tories in power, but you're right we should never have gone into coalition, let the Tories govern alone, oh wait..."

"Nick Clegg was called Kingmaker. He gave the Tories an overwhelming majority when he decided to get into bed with them. Then they backed vile Tory policy and ineptly blocked others. This let the Tories make out that things were shite because the Liberals were holding them back. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/election2010/results/ So me despising the Liberals shouldn't be that much of a surprise. They called the night of the 2015 election Cruel and Punishing. You can only be punished when you have done wrong. Except Clegg, Beeker and the rest aren't suffering for their choice, are they?"

"Agree Ryan Malcolm McGuinness. Sad to admit, I was one of those that had big hopes when I voted Norman lamb. Sadly Lib Dem personal greed became more important then party principles. I can't see me bothering to vote in local and national elections, as clearly Lib Dems proved every party is only out for themselves."
'Interested to hear what you would of preferred the outcome of 2010 to have been? The conservatives would have called another general election and like in 2015 won a majority.'

'Ryan Malcolm McGuinness Presumably you are a Labour supporter? You should actually do some research before you condemn the LibDems for going into power with the Conservatives. As a party we would much rather have cooperated with Labour but unfortunately Gordon Brown would not resign as PM despite losing the 2010 general election mainly due to the catastrophic mess Labour left with the economy. Also Labour and the LibDems would not have had enough seats to form a majority coalition and would have had to rely on all the other parties for backing to out vote the Tories. The LibDems went into power because they had a chance to push their own agenda and represent their members, such as me in government for the first time. Labour has no right to tell the LibDems what to do, we are a seperate independant party that can work with others. Its time you got your act together and formed a credible opposition instead of going back to left wing socialist ideology that has long since failed. Mind you I should not complain you have opened a door for the LibDems to take some of your more sensible ex-supporters on board.'
'"My party has more people in it because the labour membership is fake" Wow almost Trump-esque'

'Richard Franklin Never presume. I never have, and most likely never will vote Labour. You want a bone? Fine. I remember how everyone was sick of Labour at that point and I do not blame them. But I do not deal in hypotheticals and what ifs. The Tories did what we all knew they were going to do. The Liberal Democrats helped.'

"IanGoode What I would have preferred is irrelevant. What happened was the Lib Dems betrayed their voters and ethics. So don't defend that. Here is a question for you, how can I forgive someone who shows no remorse?"
'Good for you Hanna ..'

"I'm totally relating to that.. I'm so very stressed out by the state of the world just now and i try not to think about it but there are so many lessons from history that we seem to have completely bypassed as a society.... it's like nothing has been taught. It's depressing but I'm still one of the faithful X xxx her as to humanity X xxx"
'Well done!'
'Good for you Hannah Kitching. Yes, the best is yet to come if we keep working together.'

'Could someone please confirm if there is something written in the Lib Dems policy clarifying they want to stop or revert Brexshite? A friend mentioned about reading Lib.Dems policy and he feel there is no mention of stopping Brexshite? Really unclear about this. Thanks V'

'The Liberal Democrats accept the result of the the referendum and that the government is now obliged to pursue Brexit. However we do not yet know what Brexit will mean to the country and the LibDems are simply saying that the electorate should have the right to vote again on the outcome of the Brexit negotiations. Also they are criticizing the government about their lack of openness, planning and undemocratic actions.'

"In that case I'll cancel my new membership of LibDems ... I'm looking for a party to kick this entire Brexit farce into the long grass. None of Brexit makes any logical sense. It's all predicated on lies and ignorance. And as for our extreme right wing govt well what a bunch of evil buffoons. I've voted Tory for most of my life but never, ever again. So disappointed to hear LibDems spouting same phrase 'we accept referendum result and are obliged to pursue Brexit'. No you aren't! It was Advisory - read the instructions! I'm so angry, for my children, for my country, for our future. "

"Julie Addis this is very interesting fact as I've believed Lib Dems clearly want to stop the Brexshite. I'm becoming more and more concerned if there is any point campaigning, might be better to pack and move somewhere abroad & give up of this miserable, xenophobic country"

"TRimidalv VNamot I understand how you feel. I swing between utter despair and depression and angry determination to do something constructive. Trouble with giving up and leaving is then living with the feeling that the xenophobes, the liars, the right wing billionaire mogul-led media have all won . If only our so-called democracy had a more intelligent, considered, 'for the good of the country' foundation! Don't give up just yet!"
'So half the country (possibly more ) who do not want Brexfarce are not represented?'
"The EU won't let the UK leave. The EU has a cunning plan."
'Hope so Ashley.'
'Hannah Kitching is a Liberal Democrats campaign manager, lol. Prime astrotuffing there. :p'
'I wish to get a message to Theresa May if anyone can help or support: https://www.facebook.com/AAGGroupAdmin/posts/10155753624769119'
'Well done Hannah I did the same I joined LIB Dems last month Good friendly party going places to get rid of heartless Tories'
'What changed on 24th June? Was there a nuclear explosion?'
'Yes - in metaphorical terms'
'if you want nuclear - we have North Korea - it is not Jone 24th that is the problem - it is everything since then everybody should be very worried about'
'Alexandra Brach North Korea?!? What are you talking about? You are fearful of a country that is the other side of the world?'
'Charlie Chester. Grow up a bit please. Too much trolling rots YOUR brain cell .'
"No sensible answers then? Didn't think so."
'I am in a remain area but otherwise I also joined Lib Dem to make a stand so at least I can say "I tried"'
'Damien is a true patriot! Thank you! #LibDemFightback'

'Like Damien I am a long term Liberal / LibDem voter. Hopefully the party can finally break through as a major political force due to the current shortcomings with the Conservatives and Labour who are now so out of touch.'
"If you were in touch you'd know the Tories were polling around 40%. About 4 times more in touch than the Libdems on around 10% nationally."
'Simon Oliver Maximilian Johnson we will see.'
"Are there such big policy differences between Labour and Libdems that they can't merge?"

"Harry Lyon, huge differences. The LibDems are wholeheartedly behind our membership of the EU; Labour is so wishy-washy on the issue that you could believe that they are actually Bexiteers, no matter what they say. I suggest you read our Policies, and decide for yourself just how close or far apart we are from Corbyn's Labour. http://www.libdems.org.uk/issues"
'Harry Lyon If you mean that the Labour and the LibDems could become one party that could never happen. Coalition might be possible though.'
'You did breakthrough in 2010 and betrayed your voters and students getting into bed with the tories'
'Thank you a lovely story and that is why I support the LibDems.'
'Well spoken that man - we must fight back against the zombies!'

'Come 4th May, the Conservatives will find many of their previous supporters defecting. In my case, I was a conservative with a small c for half a lifetime. Part of that quiet, undemonstrative group, not heavily into politics, but who thought the party represented balance, stability, a view of the future for our kids, a firm hand on the tiller of the economy, acceptance of a social role for the state . On Europe, we were realists - not paradise, but certainly a force for good. We were quietly in the background of the Conservative party, but a huge source of votes, a mainstay of their success. I am now appalled. They have thrown all into the air in a reckless, irresponsible game of power. Alley cats that snarl, spit and hiss, grabbing at power and sod the nation, headed by a Lady from the Home Office embarrassing as much for her incapacity as her narcissism and love of her own grandeur. I will never , ever vote for them again and will do all possible to work against their interests and their influence, starting with 4th May elections. Same goes for the wife. I live in the SouthWest, where LibDems have a strong presence, and now they get two more votes.'
"Whilst your stance is admirable the problem I have here is a major doubt the Lib Dems won't just prop up another Tory coalition and keep the Tories in power."
'Annalisa Boni can you see the Tories stopping brexshit?'

'The Lib Dems did not simply "pop in" to the coalition with the Tories. The Lib Dems said before the 2010 election that if there was no majority in parliament they would talk to the party that had most seats and/or votes about forming a coalition. That was the Tories. Labour did not have the seats to form a viable coalition and in any case would only offer a coalition on the basis that it was their manifesto or nothing. In any case what would had the larger proportion of the people thought about the Lib Dems propping up the failed Brown government? Allowing the Tories to form a minority government would not have been sensible either as the Tories would have had the ability to set the political agenda to maneuver a autumn general election which they would have won comfortably or even overwhelmingly. It is not sensible to say in advance that you would not form a coalition with a particular party as that gives the other party a free negotiating had. Although next time forming a coalition will not be crucial as the Fixed Term Parliament Act curtails the power of the PM from calling an early election to his/her party\'s advantage.'

'Annalisa Boni, the elections on the 4th May are for *Council* seats, not parliamentary one. There will not be a chance to decide the fate of Britain until 2020; there will be *no* "Snap Election", just like the forecast "Snap Election" during the coalition never happened, for similar reasons. What you have on 4th May is an opportunity to bury UKIP for good and to send an unequivocal message to May and her cronies that we have had enough of her. Into the bargain, you have a chance to elect a councillor to truly represent you and your community in Local Government. A LibDem councillor who, as history shows does more for the residents than any Party Line Toeing candidate from Left or Right. A LibDem candidate who wants to ensure that your hard-earned Council Tax is spent on the things that matter and not on vanity projects and in the interests of local private backers.'

"Annalisa Boni you are clearly a Labour supporter.... and that is fine. But why keep going on about the Lib Dems propping up the Tories? They were screwed by the Tories during the coalition and lost a lot of support in order to actually do a lot of good in coalition. Take a look at what they achieved. They will not be leaping to prop them up again BUT they are not going to say that they won't enter another coalition. That would be a ridiculous thing to say and would just limit their opportunities to do good. Maybe you (as a Labour supporter) should be pushing your party to be an actual opposition to the Tories. I used to like Corbyn. I respected his views. I liked how he stood for something. But he's lost ALL respect for persistently following the Tory line regarding Brexit. He didn't even vote on the Article 50 vote in the same way as his constituents voted in the referendum. He may be a decent man but he is useless as an opposition leader. May has handed him opportunity after opportunity to really take her down during PMQs, yet he always ends up losing. Maybe if David Milliband comes back your party might be resurrected. But now they are a wasted vote. The best thing you could do for your party is vote Lib Dem."
'The Lib Dems will probably gain a lot of votes from those who spit at others for voting to Leave the EU, but I think everyone here will find that 2015 shows exactly what the public think.'
'Well said, Mr Dill.'

"The first past the post system means that every vote for anyone other than the two parties is a vote wasted. 'Why do you say that?'

"Because the system works on overall majorities. If you want a prime minister that isn't a tory, you have to vote Labour to assure that as no other party could feasibly reach an overall majority in parliament. Same thing if you want a prime minister that isn't labour. 3rd party votes are against your own strategic interests"

"The only thing third parties do is make the main parties try and appeal to that voter base by making token gestures (take the EU referendum for example). Holding politicians to account will make sure they don't vote against your interests but not to set the agenda as something for your interests. Plus, on a lazier note, it's more effort to hold politicians to account than just to vote for ones who already favour your interests and if in power, could actively pursue them"

'What you also should remember Harry Thornton is that the voter turnout for Brexit was much higher than that of a normal election. "I disagree entirely, our population is aging and many of them won't be around long enough to live with the consequences. Like the mess of global warming and climate change, our generation and generations to come will be affected and left to pick up the pieces and the consequences will be felt for a very long time. But it just goes to show they campaigned for over 40 years to leave the EU, they won on a slim majority. Officially 6% of leave voters regret their decision to vote to leave the EU. The so called benefits of leaving are unraveling as lies faster and faster every day. As a result, more people are changing their minds about brexit. I've seen it myself. But saying fighting the result isn't political suicide, it wasn't for the Eurosceptics, why would it be for the Pro Europeans? Why just sit by and let such a disaster happen and do nothing about it? Could you look your generation in the eyes and say you did nothing about it? I certainly couldn't. We can't just let coincidence dictate the future of this country. If a democracy cannot change its mind, then it ceases to be a democracy. People are being made redundant because of brexit, 44 factory workers where my dad works in Nottingham are being made redundant thanks to brexit. Staff at a Wales University are being made redundant, airlines are threatening to pull out. Businesses are moving out of the UK to other EU countries, potential investment and jobs just gone like that. I refuse to sit by and let it happen on just a coincidence"

"I know Brexit is a stupid and terrible thing. I would have voted against it if I had a vote at the time. I agree that the elderly deciding the future is unfair for the rest of us. People probably do regret their vote. But let me ask you this, if you challenge the result of a democratic referendum, what precedent does that set? It sets the idea that you can challenge any result you don't like, which undermines democracy as a concept and only causes instability inside the country. It's not that I'm happy doing nothing to oppose it, it's that there's nothing that can be done. We bite this bullet. We bite this one and maybe in a generation, we vote to go back in"

"The precedent it will set it that opposition continues to exist even when a life changing result occurs. Referendums are only meant to be used as advisory purposes only, the result isn't legally binding. We aren't ignoring voters, we're simply fighting to change opinions, just like the leavers did from the first referendum over 40 years ago. There is everything that can be done and many think so too. If you saw in London a few weeks ago 119,280 people took to the streets (more than what was expected) to protest against brexit, many people are feeling the same as I think the official figure could be even higher than 6%. Opposing and putting a stop to a suicide attempt that is brexit isn't undermining it at all. Everyday, brexit is falling apart more and more, I'm even seeing brexiters lose their appetite for it. This decision was enough to divide the country on its own. I'm sure many people feel the same then is currently showing, it's just the leave voters are bullying people into silence. They know it can be overturned, and as Nigel Farage said himself a 52-48 victory for remain would be unfinished business, but a two-thirds victory and that would be the end of it. The leave side wouldn't have stopped fighting if we had won with the same result, so why should remain stop? We can't just appease one side while ignoring the other. Democracy works for the country as a whole, not just one side."

"No Harry Thornton, democracy works for the majority of the voting population, whoever that may be. Never believe Democracy works for everyone. That was never the intention and never the reality. Referendums are advisory but you try telling the voters that. Fighting to change opinions is fine but if that's the case, you shouldn't be trying to challenge the previous result, you should try for a second referendum. Much like the SNP are doing. Protests are fine but almost entirely meaningless unless backed up by policy changes. It doesn't particularly matter if people protest, this decision was always going to be controversial either way. Protests were inevitable. If it doesn't affect the overall economy or risk endangering the government's legitimacy, nothing will come of it. You should remember that both camps are guilty of bullying voters into their own views. Never just accuse the others of doing it, both do. Having a majority of 51% in a vote is just as valid as having a majority of 90%, the result is that the majority of voters wanted it. The two thirds point could be said in every election and ultimately, a majority is a majority. The leave side wouldn't have stopped 'fighting' but I'd have told them the same thing: to accept what is, not try to be blind idealists. We can appease one side while ignoring the other, if the one side is the majority, that's how democracy works."

"The concept of representative democracy is that each voices on both sides is heard. I am very much in favour of a second referendum, that is part of the campaigning too. Unfortunately, it will once again hit the poor working class people (which many voted for brexit, but also many voted to remain). "Just to go back a bit, let me be clear on what peak child is. There are areas of the world where birth rate is above replacement rate, but these are compensated for by areas where the reverse is true (such as Italy). Bangladesh, for example, is now only just above replacement rate. There are a number of structural issues caused by having a lower birth rate than death rate, mostly to do with a lack of people for jobs. One of the effects of cutting back on child benefit and tax credits would be that. Obviously, if you have sufficient immigration, this is much less of a problem. The world does face some issues going forward with the general world population increase but a much greater problem is the obscene rate at which rich nations consume resources. The richest billion people in the world are responsible for half the world's carbon emissions. We seriously need to cut back on air travel, reduce car journey emissions, and freight and the military bear responsibility too. Oh and the reason the world's population is increasing despite the fact that we have reached peak child is that life expectancy is increasing a lot in poorer nations so that's where the next 3-5 billion people will come from."

Also, this idea of trawling the world for trade deals? What is to stop the E.U. if we leave it from doing the same in direct competition? We should be expanding the E.U. and not diminishing it. 'The operative words are "this could let them ..." - I\'m sorry but this is pure disingenuous speculation. How is the Great Repeal Bill a power grab when it makes no policy changes whatsoever? Any subsequent amendments to the legislative regime will have to be fully debated by Parliament ... And I\'m a Remainer by the way.'
"The repeal bill contains powers to amend or scrap laws without parliamentary scrutiny. That's why we should be worried."

'Incorrect - the repeal bill will not contain any powers to scrap legislation. This is an important issue - the Government has deliberately and disingenuously called it the \'great repeal bill\' as a bit of red meat to Brexiteers when in fact it does nothing of the kind. Any repealing will come at a later date and will be debated and actioned by Parliament. The purpose of the \'repeal bill\' is to incorporate all EU law currently applicable in this country onto the UK domestic statute books, to avoid us dropping off a legal cliff edge the second we leave the EU. This necessitates a number of technical changes in order for the laws to continue to work, e.g. change "[name of EU regulator]" to "[name of UK regulator]". At a later date Parliament will then be able to debate which converted laws to keep, amend or repeal. I would direct you to the Government\'s White Paper on the repeal bill, which provides three case studies for the type of necessary technical changes to be addressed by secondary legislation under the bill: 1) references to EU law (which will obviously have to be amended as we will no longer be subject to EU law); 2) references to EU institutions (which I have already mentioned); and 3) references to information sharing with the EU institutions (which may have to be tweaked). Or are you going to argue that it is realistic for Parliament to debate, one-by-one, thousands upon thousands of technical / repetitive / mechanical changes of this nature?'

'Alex Rickets You\'re right in principle I think but the issue is in its scale. What starts as a simple technical exercise can quickly become a nightmare of circular references, requiring surprising amounts of hack-and-slash to make work.To give an example, will the not-very-popular EU "right to be forgotten" law survive the GRB? Surely, the minister asks himself, nobody will miss that? Or the "cookie law"? Let\'s use those unpopular laws as a barometer. I personally don\'t trust Davis or May as far as I can throw them and the less said about BoJo and Liam "i should be in jail lol" Fox, the better. http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2016/11/30/rights-for-the-chop-how-a-henry-viii-clause-in-the-great-repeal-bill-will-undermine-democracy/'

'James Hedley we will have to wait and see the precise wording in the Bill. I think it would be politically implausible if the Government attempted anything like that, given that the opposition parties would be united against such a move (along with, in all probability, many Conservative back-benchers, thus potentially threatening the Bill itself if such a clause wasn\'t removed). For all this talk I\'ve seen about Henry VIII clauses this really isn\'t reflected at all in the Government White Paper itself, which is all we currently have to go on - it\'s all speculation. The most relevant extract of the White Paper is this one: "Crucially, we will ensure that the power will not be available where Government wishes to make a policy change which is not designed to deal with deficiencies in preserved EU derived law arising out of our exit from the EU". While I am not for a second advocating trusting politicians, I do think politically speaking it is unlikely in the extreme that the Government will propose limiting Parliament\'s role for all but mechanical changes of the kind I describe above. Although let\'s wait and see what the Bill actually says - I\'d certainly be opposed to any such move for obvious reasons, unlikely though it may be.'

The consequence was that Universities got much needed extra cash and that students who went on to earn less than ,000 pa would pay less than they would have done under Labour's system. Furthermore, the UK did not introduce controls later in the 7-year transition period, when immigration from these countries sharply increased. Immigration from EU8 accounted for on average 16% of non-British net immigration in 2004-11. "Liberal Democrats - Ever since he came into office I've had a sense that George Osborne really saw his position as a Member of Parliament as a kind of sinecure. As if we should be grateful simply for his presence - indeed, his residual charisma should be enough in those moments where he mentally appears to leave the Commons chamber. And the present lack of shame over his current multitasking is underlined by what seems to be a life rooted in detached insouciance. We should make allowance for this strange troubled creature. I would suggest he has some life sized cardboard cutouts made. The facial expression could be one of quiet trenchant certainty; yet tempered by a kindly light; and yet also with steely eyed conviction; and yet a sparkle of authentic sympathy. I am sure a skilled photographer could somehow accomplish this. With all emotional bases covered the cutouts could be distributed throughout his constituency where troubled folk could share their inner thoughts - a kind of political liturgy - with tea and cakes provided by the Conservative Club. One of the cutouts could even be placed on a bench in the Commons - but only for important debates.
